isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - AIR CONDITIONING BASIC THEORY, SYSTEM DIAGNOSIS AND SERVICE (WITH R-12 REFRIGERANT SYSTEM) - REFRIGERANT SYSTEM SERVICE - CHARGING THE AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEM (FULL CHARGE)

svcproc.title: CHARGING THE AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEM (FULL CHARGE)
svcproc.para: In preparation for charging, the air conditioning system must be evacuated of all air and moisture and be completely leak free. Refer to EVACUATING THE SYSTEM.

step1.para: Manifold suction and discharge gauge hoses remain connected to compressor service ports from evacuating operation.

Fill the charging station with the required amount of refrigerant. See specifications on truck being serviced for the required amount of refrigerant (follow charging station manufacturer's instruction). DO NOT OVERCHARGE THE SYSTEM. Excessively high head pressures during operation will result from overcharging. Make sure all valves on charging cylinder are closed after filling.

caution.para: Due to the difference in density between R-12 and HFC-134A, the amount of HFC-134A refrigerant required to charge a typical air conditioning system has been reduced. Be sure to check specifications on the truck being serviced to prevent over-charging the system and damaging the compressor.

step1.para: Connect service hose (yellow) from center manifold fitting to bottom valve on the charging station.
Open proper (see manufacturer's instructions) valve on the charging station.
With the engines shut down, open manifold discharge gauge valve and fill the air conditioning system with refrigerant.
When the air conditioning system is fully charged, close the manifold discharge valve and charging valve. Disconnect the hose from the charging valve.
After pressure test is completed, disconnect manifold gauge hoses from the compressor service ports. Replace the caps on both the suction and discharge service ports.
